text.p: 3Com Corp., the networking company that recently acquired modem maker U.S. Robotics Corp., said Monday it will likely lay off about 800 people over the next year as a result of the merger.
3Com spokeswoman Sara Powers said the company will take charges associated with the layoffs but the amount has yet to be determined.

The charges will be covered in a special merger provision to be recorded in August, so all associated charges will be taken in the company's current fiscal first quarter, which began June 1, she said.
Chief Executive Eric Benhamou told employees of the job cuts on July 1, Powers said.
Of the 800 jobs involved, Powers said, 600 are permanent positions and 200 are temporary. She said the permanent positions to be cut amount to about 4 percent of the company's 13,500 employees.
Powers said a number of top U.S. Robotics executives based in the Chicago area had already announced they were leaving the company,

Chief Financial Officer Mark Remissong, Executive Vice President of Development and Corporate Strategy Jonathan Zakin, Treasurer David Hall, human resources head Elizabeth Ryan and the vice president of the cable business unit, Semir Serazi, have all said they will pursue other opportunities, Powers said.
A formal announcement regarding the job cuts will be made either late this month or in early August, she said.
Skokie, Ill.-based U.S. Robotics and 3Com, of Santa Clara, Calif., agreed to merge in February, and last month closed the deal valued at $8.5 billion.
3Com stock added $1.25 to $49.125 on the Nasdaq market.
